metadata.case_name: Petitioners in Writ Petitions Nos. 84, 174, 188, 241 and 242 of 1966 v. Union of India

facts.text: Sir Syed Ahmad Khan conceived idea in 1870 to impart modern education to Muslims along with religious instruction due to their backwardness.
Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College Fund Committee started in May 1872 for collecting subscriptions.
School opened in May 1873, became High School in 1876, foundation stone for college laid in 1877 by Lord Litton.
Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College (M.A.O. College), Aligarh established and flourishing by 1898 when Sir Syed died.
By 1911, funds collected, Muslim University Association established for teaching university at Aligarh.
Negotiations between Association and Government of India resulted in Aligarh Muslim University Act, 1920 (1920-Act). Rs. 30 lakhs collected as condition.
M.A.O. College made basis of University, transferred to authorities under 1920-Act with properties and funds, major part contributed by Muslims.
1920-Act: Long title - establish teaching and residential Muslim University at Aligarh; dissolved societies (M.A.O. College, Muslim University Association), transferred properties to University.
Section 3: Constituted body corporate 'Aligarh Muslim University'; first members of Court all Muslims.
Section 4: Dissolved societies, vested all properties, rights in University; debts transferred.
Section 5: Powers of University including granting degrees.
Section 6: Degrees recognised by Government equivalent to other statutory universities.
Section 8: University open to all persons of either sex, race, creed or class.
Section 9: Power to make Statutes for compulsory Muslim religious instruction for Muslim students (deleted in 1951).
Section 13: Governor General as Lord Rector with inspection, inquiry, directive powers.
Section 14: Visiting Board with inspection, annulment powers.
Section 23(1) proviso: No person other than Muslim member of Court (deleted in 1951).
Section 23(2): Court supreme governing body.
Sections 28, 30: Statutes and Ordinances require approval of Governor General in Council.
First Court: 124 foundation members, all Muslims.
1951-Act: Deleted s.9 (religious instruction); amended s.8 for openness, no religious test; deleted proviso s.23(1); introduced Visitor replacing Lord Rector.
No challenge to 1951-Act until after 1965 Ordinance.

1965-Act (following Ordinance 11 of 1965): Amended s.23 - Court no longer supreme, reduced to advisory; powers to Executive Council; changed constitution of Court and Executive Council; members before 20 May 1965 ceased office.
Writ petitions filed under Art.32 challenging constitutionality of 1951 and 1965 Acts.

legal_issues.text: Whether Aligarh Muslim University was established by the Muslim minority, entitling it to administer under Art. 30(1).

petitioner_arguments.text: Aligarh University established by Muslim minority; 1951 and 1965 Acts abridge right to administer under Art. 30(1).

respondent_arguments.text: Aligarh University established by 1920-Act by Government of India, not Muslim minority; no right under Art. 30(1); Parliament can amend.
Proviso to s.23(1) does not give administration right to Muslim community; attacks under other Articles lack substance.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 30(1) read conjunctively: right to administer only institutions established by minority; Aligarh University established by 1920-Act (Central Legislature), not minority, as evidenced by s.6 recognition of degrees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Minority could not establish university with govt-recognised degrees without statute.

court_reasoning.text: Administration not vested in minority: overriding powers with Lord Rector, Visiting Board, Governor General; Court members Muslim but electors included non-Muslims; no violation of Art. 30(1).
Art. 26: University not established/maintained by minority; property vested in University, not minority.

No violation of Arts. 25, 29 (no impact on religion/culture); Art. 14 (each university class by itself); Art. 19 (no deprivation of association/property rights); Art. 31 (property surrendered in 1920, vested in University).

holdings.text: Aligarh Muslim University established by 1920-Act, not Muslim minority; no right under Art. 30(1) to administer.
1951 and 1965 Acts not violative of Arts. 14, 19, 25, 26, 29, 31; within Parliament's competence.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re, The Kerala Education Bill, 1957
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 30(1) protects pre-Constitution institutions but establish and administer read conjunctively.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pujari Committee, Ajmer v. Syed Hussain Ali
precedents_cited.relevance: Right to administer may be lost if never vested or surrendered.

precedents_cited.case_name: St. Davids College, Lampeter v. Ministry of Education
precedents_cited.relevance: University distinguished by granting own degrees.

statutes_cited.name: Aligarh Muslim University Act, 1920
statutes_cited.relevance: Established University as statutory body; govt control; degrees recognised.

statutes_cited.name: Aligarh Muslim University (Amendment) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Deleted religious instruction, Muslim-only Court proviso; introduced Visitor.

statutes_cited.name: Aligarh Muslim University (Amendment) Act, 1965
statutes_cited.relevance: Reduced Court powers, changed constitution; increased Executive Council powers.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged for violating minority rights, equality, etc.; held not violated.

statutes_cited.name: University Grants Commission Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Post-1956, only statutory universities grant recognised degrees.

statutes_cited.name: Societies Registration Act, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: M.A.O. College and Muslim University Association registered societies dissolved by 1920-Act.

outcome.summary: The writ petitions challenging the constitutionality of the Aligarh Muslim University Amendment Acts of 1951 and 1965 were dismissed, holding that the University was established by statute (1920-Act), not by the Muslim minority, and the amendments do not violate any fundamental rights under Arts. 14, 19, 25, 26, 29, 30 or 31.

key_quotes.text: "The words establish and administer in the Article must be read conjunctively and so read it gives the right to the minority to administer an educational institution provided it has been established by it."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It was clearly brought into existence by the 1920-Act for it could not have been brought into existence otherwise."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The Aligarh University not having been established by the Muslim minority, any amendment of the 1920-Act by which it was established, would be within the legislative power of Parliament."
key_quotes.speaker: court
